sen.j: 都久夫須麻神社（つくぶすまじんじゃ）は滋賀県長浜市の竹生島にある神社。
sen.e: Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine on Chikubushima Island in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.
Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine on Chikubushima Island in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.
Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine on Chikubushima Island in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 竹生島神社（ちくぶじまじんじゃ）とも。
sen.e: It is also called Chikubujima-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: この文中でのみ、原文に従って「ちくぶじま」と読み、他の文中では「ちくぶしま」と濁らず表記しました。
sen.e: It is also called Chikubujima-jinja Shrine.
It is also called Chikubujima-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and a prefectural shrine in the old shrine ranking.
It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and a prefectural shrine in the old shrine ranking.
It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and a prefectural shrine in the old shrine ranking.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 江戸時代までは神仏習合であり、隣接する宝厳寺と一体化していた。
sen.e: Until the Edo Period, Shinto and Buddhism were syncretized and so the shrine was unified with the adjoining Hogon-ji Temple.
Until the Edo Period, Shinto and Buddhism were syncretized and so the shrine was unified with the adjoining Hogon-ji Temple.
Until the Edo Period, Shinto and Buddhism were syncretized and so the shrine was unified with the adjoining Hogon-ji Temple.

sen.j: 社伝では、雄略天皇3年（420年）に浅井姫命を祀る小祠が作られたのに始まると伝える。
sen.e: The shrine tradition says that it started when shoshi (a small shrine) to enshrine Azaihime no mikoto was made in 420.
The shrine tradition says that it started when shoshi (a small shrine) to enshrine Azaihime no mikoto was made in 420.
The shrine tradition says that it started when shoshi (a small shrine) to enshrine Azaihime no mikoto was made in 420.

sen.j: 『近江国風土記』には、夷服岳（伊吹山）の多多美比古命が姪にあたる浅井岳（金糞岳）の浅井姫命と高さ比べをし、負けた多多美比古命が怒って浅井姫命の首を斬ったところ、湖に落ちた首が竹生島になったという記述がある。
sen.e: "Omi no Kuni Fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Omi Province) says when Tatamihiko no mikoto of Ibuki no oka Mountain (Mt. Ibuki) competed with his niece Azaihime no mikoto of Azai dake Mountain (Kanakuso dake Mountain) for height, he lost and in anger cut off her head, which fell into the lake and became Chikubushima Island.
sen.cmt: 多多美比古命は男だと解釈して、his を使いました。
sen.e: "Omi no Kuni Fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Omi Province) says when Tatamihiko no mikoto of Ibuki no oka Mountain (Mt. Ibuki) competed with his niece Azaihime no mikoto of Azai dake Mountain (Kanakuso dake Mountain) for height, he lost and in anger cut off her head, which fell into the lake and became Chikubushima Island.

"Omi no Kuni Fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Omi Province) says when Tatamihiko no mikoto of Ibuki no oka Mountain (Mt. Ibuki) competed with his niece Azaihime no mikoto of Azai dake Mountain (Kanakuso dake Mountain) for height, he lost and in anger cut off her head, which fell into the lake and became Chikubushima Island.

sen.j: 一説には首が沈む時に「都布都布（つふつふ）」という音がしたので「都布失島」という名前になったとも、最初に生えたのが竹であったことから「竹生島」という名前になったともいう。
sen.e: It is also said that when her head sank it sounded 'Tsufu, tsufu' and so the island was named 'Tsufushitsu Island', or it was named 'Chikubushima Island' because the first grown plants there were bamboos (their Chinese character is read 'chiku').
sen.cmt: 都布失島の正確な読み方が不明です。
sen.e: It is also said that when her head sank it sounded 'Tsufu, tsufu' and so the island was named 'Tsufushitsu Island', or it was named 'Chikubushima Island' because the first grown plants there were bamboos (their Chinese character is read 'chiku').

It is also said that when her head sank it sounded 'Tsufu, tsufu' and so the island was named 'Tsufushitsu Island', or it was named 'Chikubushima Island' because the first grown plants there were bamboos (their Chinese character is read 'chiku').

sen.j: 神亀元年（724年）、聖武天皇の夢に天照大神が現れ、「琵琶湖に小島があり、そこは弁才天（弁才天）の聖地であるから寺院を建立せよ」との神託があったので、行基を勅使として竹生島に遣わし寺院を開基させた。
sen.e: In 724, Emperor Shomu had a dream of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) and got her message, 'There is a small island in Lake Biwa and as it is the holy place of Benzaiten, you must found a temple', so he sent Gyoki to Chikubushima Island as an Imperial envoy and had a temple built.

In 724, Emperor Shomu had a dream of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) and got her message, 'There is a small island in Lake Biwa and as it is the holy place of Benzaiten, you must found a temple', so he sent Gyoki to Chikubushima Island as an Imperial envoy and had a temple built.

In 724, Emperor Shomu had a dream of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) and got her message, 'There is a small island in Lake Biwa and as it is the holy place of Benzaiten, you must found a temple', so he sent Gyoki to Chikubushima Island as an Imperial envoy and had a temple built.

sen.j: 行基は弁財天の像を彫刻して本尊とした。
sen.e: Gyoki carved a statue of Benzaiten and made it the idol thereof.
Gyoki carved a statue of Benzaiten and made it the idol thereof.
Gyoki carved a statue of Benzaiten and made it the idol thereof.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では小社に列する。
sen.e: It is listed as a small shrine in Engishiki Jinmyocho (a list of shrines).
It is listed as a small shrine in Engishiki Jinmyocho (a list of shrines).
It is listed as a small shrine in Engishiki Jinmyocho (a list of shrines).

sen.j: 中世ごろから、比叡山の影響のもとに神仏習合が進み、弁財天を本地仏とし、「日本三大弁財天」の一つと称されるようになった。
sen.e: Beginning in the Medieval Period, Shinto and Buddhism advanced toward syncretization under the influence of Mt. Hiei (Enryaku-ji Temple), and the shrine came to be called one of the 'Three major Benzaiten in Japan' with Benzaiten as its honji-butsu (original Buddhist divine).
sen.cmt: 「比叡山の影響」は、延暦寺の影響と解釈しました。
sen.e: Beginning in the Medieval Period, Shinto and Buddhism advanced toward syncretization under the influence of Mt. Hiei (Enryaku-ji Temple), and the shrine came to be called one of the 'Three major Benzaiten in Japan' with Benzaiten as its honji-butsu (original Buddhist divine).

Beginning in the Medieval Period, Shinto and Buddhism advanced toward syncretization under the influence of Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, and the shrine came to be called one of the 'Three major Benzaiten in Japan' with Benzaiten as its honji-butsu (original Buddhist divine).
sen.cmt: チェッカーのコメントどおり山号なのでMt. Hiei (Enryaku-ji Temple)→Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple

sen.j: 日本最古の弁財天、弁財天の発祥地とも言われる。
sen.e: It is said to be the oldest Benzaiten in Japan or the birthplace of Benzaiten.
It is said to be the oldest Benzaiten in Japan or the birthplace of Benzaiten.
It is said to be the oldest Benzaiten in Japan or the birthplace of Benzaiten.

sen.j: 明治に入り、明治新政府は神仏分離令を出した。
sen.e: In the Meiji Period, the New Meiji Government issued the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism.
In the Meiji Period, the New Meiji Government issued the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism.
In the Meiji Period, the New Meiji Government issued the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism.

sen.j: これに基づき大津県庁は宝厳寺を廃寺にして神社とし、延喜式神名帳に見える「都久夫須麻神社」と称するよう命じた。
sen.e: Based on this, the then Otsu Prefectural Government ordered the abolition of Hogon-ji Temple, making it a shrine and naming it 'Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine' as was in the list of Engishiki Jinmyocho.
Based on this, the Otsu Prefectural Government ordered the abolition of Hogon-ji Temple, making it a shrine and naming it 'Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine' as was in the list of Engishiki Jinmyocho.
sen.cmt: then を削除しました。the then Otsu Prefectural Government
sen.e: Based on this, the Otsu Prefectural Government ordered the abolition of Hogon-ji Temple, making it a shrine and naming it 'Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine' as was in the list of Engishiki Jinmyocho.

sen.j: 日本全国の崇敬者の強い要望により宝厳寺の廃寺は免れて寺院と神社の両方が並存することとなった。
sen.e: Strongly requested by worshippers across the nation, Hogon-ji Temple escaped abolition, and it was decided that the temple and the shrine could coexist.
Strongly requested by worshippers across the nation, Hogon-ji Temple escaped abolition, and it was decided that the temple and the shrine could coexist.
Strongly requested by worshippers across the nation, Hogon-ji Temple escaped abolition; this meant that the temple and the shrine coexisted.
sen.cmt: and it was decided→; this meantcould coexist→coexisted

sen.j: 明治7年（1874年）に都久夫須麻神社と宝厳寺の境界が決められ、明治16年（1883年）に両者の財産が区別された。
sen.e: In 1874, the division between Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple was determined and in 1883, the properties of them were distinguished.
In 1874, the division between Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple was determined and in 1883, the properties of them were distinguished.
In 1874, the division between Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple was determined and in 1883, the properties of them were distinguished.

sen.j: 以降、都久夫須麻神社と宝厳寺は別の法人となっているが、今日でも都久夫須麻神社の本殿と宝厳寺の観音堂は舟廊下で直接連絡しており、両者は不可分のものとなっている。
sen.e: Since then, Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple have been different corporations, however, the main building of Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Kannon-do hall of Hogon-ji Temple are still directly connected by a corridor called Huna-roka, and so they cannot be separated.

Since then, Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple have been different corporations, however, the main building of Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Kannon-do hall of Hogon-ji Temple are still directly connected by a corridor called Huna-roka, and so they cannot be separated.

Since then, Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Hogon-ji Temple have been different corporations, however, the main building of Tsukubusuma-jinja Shrine and Kannon-do hall of Hogon-ji Temple are still directly connected by a corridor called Huna-roka, and so they cannot be separated.

Cultural Properties

sen.j: 本殿は、関白豊臣秀吉が時の天皇の迎える施設として伏見城内に建設した「日暮御殿」を豊臣秀頼が移建・寄進したもので、内部は狩野永徳、狩野光信の筆と高台寺蒔絵によって黄金色に飾られている。
sen.e: The main building, which was once in Fushimi Castle built by the chief advisor to the emperor Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI to welcome the then emperor and called 'Higurashi no goten', was brought and rebuilt, and the inside of the building is decorated with paintings by Eitoku KANO and Mitunobu KANO, and Kodai-ji makie (gold lacquer work)

The main building, which was once in Fushimi-jo Castle built by Kanpaku (the chief advisor to the Emperor) Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI to welcome the then emperor and called 'Higurashi no goten' (Sunset Palace), was brought and rebuilt, and the inside of the building is decorated with paintings by Eitoku KANO and Mitsunobu KANO, and Kodai-ji makie (gold lacquer work).
sen.cmt: Fushimi Castle > Fushimi-jo Castlethe chief advisor to the emperor > Kanpaku (the chief advisor to the Emperor) 'Higurashi no goten' > 'Higurashi no goten' (Sunset Palace)Mitunobu > Mitsunobuピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: The main building, which was once in Fushimi-jo Castle built by Kanpaku (the chief advisor to the Emperor) Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI to welcome the then emperor and called 'Higurashi no goten' (Sunset Palace), was brought and rebuilt, and the inside of the building is decorated with paintings by Eitoku KANO and Mitsunobu KANO, and Kodai-ji makie (gold lacquer work).

sen.j: 安土桃山時代の文化を伝える建造物として国宝に指定されている。
sen.e: It is designated as a national treasure as a building that conveys the culture of the Azuchi-momoyama Period.
It is designated as a national treasure as a building that conveys the culture of the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: the Azuchi-momoyama Period. > the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 常行殿拝殿は琵琶湖に面する景勝地にあり、眼下の断崖上に竜神拝所がある。
sen.e: The worship hall of Jogyo-den is located in a beautiful spot facing Lake Biwa, and you can see Ryujin Haisho (place of prayer) on the cliff below.
The worship hall of Jogyo-den is located in a beautiful spot facing Lake Biwa, and you can see Ryujin Haisho (place of prayer) on the cliff below.
The worship hall of Jogyo-den is located in a beautiful spot facing Lake Biwa, and you can see Ryujin Haisho (place of prayer) on the cliff below.

sen.j: ここから土器を海に投げると願いが竜神により成就されるという「かわらけ投げ」という風習が残る。
sen.e: If you throw earthenware from here into the lake, your wish will be fulfilled by Ryujin, which is a custom called 'Kawara nage'.
If you throw earthenware from here into the lake, your wish will be fulfilled by Ryujin, which is a custom called 'Kawara nage'.
